sect1.title: Fill Series
sect1.para: Fill series tool can substatially speed up the filling of related values into a sheet. The tool is able to fill cells according to a linear or exponential serie. In addition, dates having certain intervals can be filled automatically using the tool. For example, series like 2, 5, 8, 11, ..., or, 2, 4, 8, 16, ..., or, Jan 1st 2003, Jan 3rd 2003, Jan 5th 2003, ..., can be automatically filled into a sheet by using the tool.

sect2.title: Filling Linear and Growth (Exponential) Series
sect2.para: Each serie has to have an initial first value and a step value. In linear series, the next value is generated using the formula `V(n+1) := V(n) + step', where V(n) is the previous value in the serie. In growth series, the next value is generated using the formula `V(n+1) := V(n) * step'.

In order to use the tool, set an initial value into the first cell of a serie. Then paint a column or a row area so that the first cell in the selection contains the initial value. Now select the ``Fill'' menu item in ``Edit'' menu, and then select ``Series...'' in the popup submenu.

If you painted a column, select ``Columns'' in ``Series in'' frame. Otherwise, let the default setting be ``Rows''. Then type the ``Step Value'' into the corresponding entry box. As described already, there are two types of series that the tool supports: linear and growth (exponential) series. Select the one you want to use by checking the corresponding radio button on. If you want to stop filling after certain limit is reached, you can also specify the ``Stop Value'' in the corresponding entry box.

sect2.title: Filling Date Series
sect2.para: In order to fill dates, set an initial date into the first cell and then select a row or a column to be filled, and start the tool just like in the case of a linear serie filling. But in this case, now select ``Date'' button in the ``Type'' frame in order to make the ``Date unit'' frame sensitive for user input. In the ``Date unit'' frame you can select the date unit to be stepped in each step. Date unit can be a day, a weekday (weekends are skipped), a month, or a year. For example, if you select ``Weekday'' the tool steps in each iteration the number of working days specified in the ``Step Value'' entry.
